Adaptive Model Pruning and Personalization for Federated Learning over Wireless Networks

Xiaonan Liu,  Tharmalingam Ratnarajah, , Mathini Sellathurai, , and Yonina C. Eldar,  X. Liu and T. Ratnarajah are with the Institute for Digital Communications, The University of Edinburgh, U.K. (e-mail: {xliu8, t.ratnarajah}@ed.ac.uk). M. Sellathurai is with the Department of Engineering and Physical Science (EPS), Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, U.K. (e-mail: m.sellathurai@hw.ac.uk)Yonina C. Eldar is with the Faculty of Mathematics and Computer Science, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot 7610001, Israel (e-mail: yonina.eldar@weizmann.ac.il)
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) enables distributed learning across edge devices while protecting data privacy. However, the learning accuracy decreases due to the heterogeneity of devices’ data, and the computation and communication latency increase when updating large-scale learning models on devices with limited computational capability and wireless resources. We consider a FL framework with partial model pruning and personalization to overcome these challenges. This framework splits the learning model into a global part with model pruning shared with all devices to learn data representations and a personalized part to be fine-tuned for a specific device, which adapts the model size during FL to reduce both computation and communication latency and increases the learning accuracy for devices with non-independent and identically distributed data. The computation and communication latency and convergence of the proposed FL framework are mathematically analyzed. To maximize the convergence rate and guarantee learning accuracy, Karush–Kuhn–Tucker (KKT) conditions are deployed to jointly optimize the pruning ratio and bandwidth allocation. Finally, experimental results demonstrate that the proposed FL framework achieves a remarkable reduction of approximately 50%percent5050\% computation and communication latency compared with FL with partial model personalization.

Index Terms:
Adaptive partial model pruning and personalization, communication and computation latency, federated learning, wireless networks.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a promising approach for protecting data privacy and facilitating distributed learning across diverse domains, such as healthcare, finance, and mobile devices [1, 2], where multiple edge devices share only the model/gradients with an edge server to collaboratively train a learning model [3]. Although FL preserves privacy, it still has significant challenges in computation and communication [4, 5]. Data heterogeneity in different devices may lead to unstable training of FL and further result in poor generalization ability of the global model and low learning accuracy. Furthermore, devices with limited computational capabilities lead to high computation latency. On the communication side, with an increasing number of edge devices, the limited communication resources, e.g., bandwidth and energy, may impede devices from effectively contributing to model aggregation, which results in high transmission latency and has a negative effect on the convergence rate and learning accuracy [6].

To address data heterogeneity, personalized FL (PFL) and federated feature matching (FedFM) were considered in [7, 8, 9] and [10], respectively. In [7], PFL based on model similarity was proposed to leverage a classifier-based similarity for personalized model aggregation without incurring extra communication overhead. In [8], a new PFL algorithm called FL with dynamic weight adjustment was proposed to leverage the edge server to calculate personalized aggregation weights based on collected models from devices, which captures similarities between devices and improves PFL learning accuracy by encouraging collaboration among devices with similar data distribution. In [9], hierarchical PFL (HPFL) was considered in massive mobile edge computing (MEC) networks. HPFL combined the objectives of training loss minimization and round latency minimization while jointly determining the optimal bandwidth allocation and the edge server scheduling policy in a hierarchical learning framework. In [10], FedFM was proposed to guide each device’s features to match shared category-wise anchors (landmarks in feature space), which mitigated the negative effects of data heterogeneity in FL by aligning each device’s feature space. However, PFL and FedFM in [7, 8, 9, 10] still need to transmit the whole learning model to the server for similarity/anchors calculation and model aggregation.

To deal with the high-latency issue in PFL, FL with partial model personalization is introduced in [11, 12]. This FL framework splits the learning model into a global part, shared with all devices to learn data representations, and a personalized part, fine-tuned for a specific device based on the heterogeneity of the local dataset. In each global communication round, the edge server broadcasts the current global part to devices. Then, each device performs one or more steps of stochastic gradient descent to update both the global and personalized parts and transmits only the updated global part to the edge server for model aggregation, further reducing the transmission latency. Meanwhile, the updated personalized part is kept locally on the device to initialize another update in the next global communication round. In [11], two FL algorithms for training partially personalized models were introduced, where the shared and personal parameters are updated simultaneously or alternately on devices. In [12], the authors proved that through optimizing the split point of the learning model, it is possible to find global and personalized parameters that allow each device to fit its local dataset perfectly and break the curse of data heterogeneity in several settings. However, the communication and computation overheads of partial model personalization in [11] and [12] over wireless networks are not explored.

To improve the learning efficiency, federated pruning was proposed in [13, 14, 15], where the model size is adapted during the training/inference phase or both of these two phases to decrease computation and communication overhead. FL pruning offers benefits in model size reduction without sacrificing the learning accuracy of the original model [16]. In [13], model pruning was adopted before local gradient calculation to reduce the local model computation and gradient communication latency in FL over wireless networks. By removing the edge devices with low computation capability and bad channel conditions, device selection was also considered to save the communication overhead and reduce the model aggregation error caused by model pruning. In [14], a low-complexity adaptive pruning method called PruneFL was proposed for resource-limited devices, which determined a desired model size that achieves similar prediction accuracy as the original model but with less training time. In [15], hierarchical FL with model pruning over wireless networks was introduced to reduce the neural network size, decreasing computation and communication latency while guaranteeing a similar learning accuracy as the original model. Nevertheless, the proposed FL pruning methods in [13, 14, 15] are unsuitable for devices with non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data. Therefore, designing an FL framework with high communication and computation efficiency and adaptability to non-IID datasets is essential.

In addition, unlike FL with personalization or pruning, proper resource allocation and device scheduling also enable computation and communication-efficient FL [17, 18, 19, 20, 21]. Specifically, in [17], by optimizing time allocation, bandwidth allocation, power control, and computation frequency, an iterative algorithm was proposed to minimize the total energy consumption for local computation and wireless transmission of FL. In [18], a probabilistic device selection scheme was proposed to minimize the FL convergence time and the FL training loss in a joint learning, wireless resource allocation, and user selection problem. In [19], the Hungarian algorithm was used to find an optimal device selection and resource block allocation to minimize the FL loss function. In [20], the communication and computation costs were minimized by deploying successive convex approximation and Hungarian algorithms to optimize bandwidth, computation frequency, power allocation, and sub-carrier assignment. In [21], dubbed Bayesian air aggregation FL (BAAF) was proposed to effectively mitigate noise and fading effects induced by the channel, and to handle the statistical heterogeneity of devices’ data, controlled BAAF was developed to allow for appropriate local updates by the devices. Although the proposed device scheduling and resource allocation approaches in [17, 18, 19, 20, 21] effectively alleviate communication costs, uploading the entire learning model still poses a challenge for devices with poor channel conditions.

Motivated by the aforementioned challenges, we propose a computation and communication-efficient wireless FL framework with partial model pruning and personalization. First, we mathematically model the computation and communication latency of the proposed FL framework. Second, a convergence analysis is presented. Then, Karush–Kuhn–Tucker (KKT) conditions are deployed to derive closed-form solutions for the pruning ratio and bandwidth allocation under latency and bandwidth thresholds, which achieve a high learning accuracy and low computation and communication latency. The main contributions are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We propose a communication and computation-efficient FL framework with partial model pruning and personalization to adapt to data heterogeneity across different devices and dynamical wireless environments.

  • •

    We mathematically model the computation and communication latency of the proposed FL framework. We then analyze an upper bound on the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm of gradients of the method. Next, we jointly optimize the pruning ratio of the global part and bandwidth allocation to maximize the convergence rate and guarantee learning accuracy.

  • •

    Under the latency and bandwidth thresholds, the optimization problem is divided into two sub-problems. Karush–Kuhn–Tucker (KKT) conditions are used to solve these sub-problems and calculate the optimal solutions of the pruning ratio and bandwidth allocation.

  • •

    Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed FL framework achieves comparable learning accuracy to FL only with model personalization and leads to a reduction of approximately 50%percent5050\% in computation and communication latency.

In the rest of this paper, the system model and problem formulation are presented in Section II. Convergence analysis and problem transformation are presented in Section III. Pruning ratio and bandwidth fraction optimization are presented in Section IV. Experimental results and conclusions are given in Section V and Section VI, respectively.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

In this section, we detail the system model for FL with partial model personalization over wireless networks.

II-A FL with Partial Model Personalization Architecture

We consider an edge server with multiple antennas providing wireless service for 𝒦={k=1,2,…,K}𝒦𝑘12…𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{k=1,2,...,K\} mobile devices. The k𝑘kth edge device has a dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} is the number of data samples. Without loss of generality, we assume that there is no overlap between datasets from different devices, namely, 𝒟n∩𝒟k=∅,(∀n,k∈𝒦)subscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝒟𝑘for-all𝑛𝑘𝒦\mathcal{D}_{n}\cap\mathcal{D}_{k}=\emptyset,(\forall n,k\in\mathcal{K}). The whole dataset and the total number of data samples are denoted as 𝒟=∪{𝒟k}k=1K𝒟superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑘1𝐾\mathcal{D}=\cup\{\mathcal{D}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K} and D=∑k=1KDk𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘D=\sum_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}, respectively.

The main objective of traditional FL algorithms, such as federated averaging (FedAvg) [3], is to find an optimal global model 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*} that minimizes the global loss function F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\bm{w}):

F​(𝒘)=∑k=1KDkD​Fk​(𝒘),𝐹𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘F(\bm{w})=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{D_{k}}{D}F_{k}(\bm{w}), (1)

where the local loss Fk​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘F_{k}(\bm{w}) of the k𝑘kth device is calculated as

Fk​(𝒘)=1Dk​∑i=1Dkfk​(𝒙i,yi,𝒘).subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝒘F_{k}(\bm{w})=\frac{1}{D_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{D_{k}}f_{k}(\bm{x}_{i},y_{i},\bm{w}). (2)

In (2), fk​(𝒙i,yi,𝒘)subscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝒘f_{k}(\bm{x}_{i},y_{i},\bm{w}) is the loss function, 𝒙isubscript𝒙𝑖\bm{x}_{i} is the i𝑖ith input data sample, and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the corresponding labeled output.

The objective function in (1) may not have a global model 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} that fits all devices in practical FL systems, especially when the data distribution in devices is non-IID or heterogeneous, namely, statistical heterogeneity. The local optimal models may drift significantly from each other and lead to a poor generalization of each device because of statistical data heterogeneity. Modern deep learning models usually have a multi-layer architecture. Generally, lower layers (close to the input) are responsible for feature extraction, and upper layers (close to the output) focus on complex pattern recognition. Therefore, based on the application domain, often either the input layer or the output layer of the model can be personalized. We may thus split the model 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} into a global part 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} shared by all devices and a personalized part 𝒗ksubscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k} specific to the k𝑘kth device, i.e., 𝒘=[𝒖,𝒗k].𝒘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘\bm{w}=[\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}]. The objective functions in (1) and (2) can then be rewritten as

min𝒖,{𝒗k}k=1K⁡F​(𝒖,𝒗k)=∑k=1KDkD​Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k),subscript𝒖superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑘1𝐾𝐹𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘\min_{\bm{u},\{\bm{v}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}}F(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k})=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{D_{k}}{D}F_{k}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}), (3)

and

Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)=1Dk​∑i=1Dkfk​(𝒙i,yi,𝒖,𝒗k).subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘F_{k}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k})=\frac{1}{D_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{D_{k}}f_{k}(\bm{x}_{i},y_{i},\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}). (4)

II-B Learning Process

In FL with partial model personalization, the personalized parts are only updated in local devices, and the global parts are updated in local devices and aggregated in the edge server. Therefore, the learning process includes global part broadcasting, local model updating, and global part uploading. To quantify the training overhead of the proposed FL framework, we model computation and communication latency. The learning process is detailed as follows:

II-B1 Global Part Broadcasting

In the g𝑔gth global communication round, the edge server broadcasts the global part 𝒖gsuperscript𝒖𝑔\bm{u}^{g} to devices by downlink transmission. The downlink transmission rate is very high in a practical system due to sufficient channel bandwidth. Consequently, the transmission latency of global part broadcasting is neglected.

II-B2 Local Model Updating

Local model updating includes personalized and global parts updating. According to [11], updating the personalized and global parts alternatively, so-called LocalAlt, guarantees a higher learning accuracy. In LocalAlt, the personalized part 𝒗kgsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔\bm{v}_{k}^{g} of the k𝑘kth device is first updated τ𝒗subscript𝜏𝒗\tau_{\bm{v}} iterations, and the global part remains the same. Then, the global part 𝒖kgsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔\bm{u}_{k}^{g} updates τ𝒖subscript𝜏𝒖\tau_{\bm{u}} iterations using the updated personalized part 𝒗kg,τ𝒗superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔subscript𝜏𝒗\bm{v}_{k}^{g,\tau_{\bm{v}}}.

Based on (3) and (4), when the k𝑘kth edge device obtains the global part from the edge server, the objective of the k𝑘kth device is to find

𝒗k∗​(𝒖kg)=arg⁡min𝒗kg⁡Fk​(𝒖kg,𝒗kg).superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔\bm{v}_{k}^{*}(\bm{u}_{k}^{g})=\arg\min_{\bm{v}_{k}^{g}}F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k}^{g},\bm{v}_{k}^{g}). (5)

It is possible that the edge device has limited computation capacity; thus, updating personalized and global parts over the whole dataset is time-consuming. As a result, we consider stochastic gradient descent (SGD) where the k𝑘kth edge device utilizes a subset of its dataset to update the local model. Within the g𝑔gth global communication round, the personalized part updating in the t𝑡tth iteration is written as

Based on the updated personalized part 𝒗kg,τ𝒗superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔subscript𝜏𝒗\bm{v}_{k}^{g,\tau_{\bm{v}}}, the global part updating in the t𝑡tth iteration is denoted as

II-B3 Uplink Transmission of Global Part

After personalized and global parts updating in the k𝑘kth edge device, the updated global part 𝒖kgsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔\bm{u}_{k}^{g} is delivered to the edge server by uplink transmission. We consider an orthogonal frequency-division multiple access (OFDMA) protocol for uplink transmission [22, 23]. The transmission rate between the edge server and the k𝑘kth device is expressed as

where q^^𝑞\hat{q} is the quantization bit.

II-B4 Global Part Aggregation

When the edge server receives the global parts from edge devices, it averages them into a global part by

𝒖g+1=1|𝒦g|​∑k∈𝒦g𝒖kg,superscript𝒖𝑔11subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔\bm{u}^{g+1}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{K}_{g}|}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}}\bm{u}_{k}^{g}, (11)

where 𝒦gsubscript𝒦𝑔\mathcal{K}_{g} is the set of edge devices participating in global part aggregation in the g𝑔gth global communication round, and |𝒦g|subscript𝒦𝑔|\mathcal{K}_{g}| is the number of edge devices.

Then, the edge server transmits the aggregated global part 𝒖g+1superscript𝒖𝑔1{\bm{u}}^{g+1} to the edge devices for the next round of global and personalized parts updating. The edge server is usually equipped with a high computation unit, such as a graphics processing unit (GPU); thus, the latency of the global part aggregation is ignored.

II-C Local Computation and Uplink Latency

Because of the high computation capability of the edge server and the sufficient bandwidth in downlink transmission, the computation latency of model aggregation in the edge server and downlink transmission latency of the global part are ignored. We mainly consider the latency of uplink transmission of the global part and local model updating, which is calculated as

II-D Optimization Problem Formulation

Given the previously mentioned system model, the objective of this work is to minimize the global loss function F​(𝒖,𝒗k)𝐹𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘F(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}) in (3) under the bandwidth and latency thresholds, and the optimization problem is formulated as

minbkgsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑔\displaystyle\min_{{b}_{k}^{g}}~{}~{} F​(𝒖,𝒗k),𝐹𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘\displaystyle F(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}), (15)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t.~{}~{} Tg≤Tth,subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑇th\displaystyle T_{g}\leq T_{\text{th}}, (16)
∑k=1Kbkg≤1,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑔1\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}{b}_{k}^{g}\leq 1, (17)
bkg∈[0,1].superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑔01\displaystyle{b}_{k}^{g}\in[0,1]. (18)

In (16), Tthsubscript𝑇thT_{\text{th}} represents the computation and communication latency constraint, and constraints in (17) and (18) represent the bandwidth fraction thresholds. To this end, we first consider partial model pruning to guarantee learning accuracy and decrease computation and communication latency. Then, we analyze the convergence bound of the proposed FL with partial model pruning and personalization algorithm and transform the optimization problem in (15) into optimizing the convergence bound.

III Convergence Analysis and Problem Transformation

In this section, we start with model pruning of the global part. Then, we theoretically characterize the convergence bound of the proposed FL framework and transform the optimization problem into a joint pruning ratio and bandwidth allocation optimization.

III-A Model Pruning

In wireless FL frameworks with partial model personalization, updating learning models on edge devices with limited computation capabilities and exchanging them between edge servers and devices under poor wireless channel conditions may lead to high computation and communication latency, even if only the global part 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} is shared among devices. We therefore consider pruning to reduce the size of the learning model.

Effectively pruning insignificant weights may reduce the model size without sacrificing learning performance. We consider an unstructured pruning method [24], whose the importance of weight is computed by a squared difference between prediction errors obtained with and without the corresponding model weight. For example, the importance of the j𝑗jth model weight of the global part is calculated as

Ik,j=(Fk​(𝒖k,𝒗k)−Fk​(𝒖k,𝒗k|uk,j=0))2.subscript𝐼𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝒖𝑘subscript𝒗𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝒖𝑘conditionalsubscript𝒗𝑘subscript𝑢𝑘𝑗02I_{k,j}=\left(F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k},\bm{v}_{k})-F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k},\bm{v}_{k}|u_{k,j}=0)\right)^{2}. (19)

Weight importance increases as the corresponding error in (19) grows. Nevertheless, calculating Ik,jsubscript𝐼𝑘𝑗I_{k,j} for all model weights of the global part is time-consuming. To alleviate the computational burden, an alternative approach is to calculate the difference between the updated and non-updated j𝑗jth model weight, denoted as

I^k,j=|u^k,j−uk,j|,subscript^𝐼𝑘𝑗subscript^𝑢𝑘𝑗subscript𝑢𝑘𝑗\hat{I}_{k,j}=|\hat{u}_{k,j}-{u}_{k,j}|, (20)

where u^k,jsubscript^𝑢𝑘𝑗\hat{u}_{k,j} and uk,jsubscript𝑢𝑘𝑗{u}_{k,j} are the updated j𝑗jth and non-updated j𝑗jth model weight of the global part in the k𝑘kth device, respectively. Calculating the importance using (20) is straightforward, as the updated global part weight u^k,jsubscript^𝑢𝑘𝑗\hat{u}_{k,j} is already available through backpropagation.

The proposed FL with partial model pruning and personalization is shown in Fig. 1, where the personalized parts are only updated in local devices, and the global parts are pruned and updated in local devices and aggregated in the edge server. The learning process is updated as follows:

III-A1 Local Model Updating

Based on the local model updating in Section II.B, after τ𝒗subscript𝜏𝒗\tau_{\bm{v}} iterations of updating the personalized part 𝒗kg,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔𝑡\bm{v}_{k}^{g,t}, we begin updating the global part 𝒖kgsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔\bm{u}_{k}^{g} of the k𝑘kth device. The edge devices first update the global part 𝒖kgsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔\bm{u}_{k}^{g} by 𝒖kg−η𝒖​∇Fk​(𝒖kg,𝒗kg,τ𝒗,ξkg)superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔subscript𝜂𝒖∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔subscript𝜏𝒗superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑔\bm{u}_{k}^{g}-\eta_{\bm{u}}\nabla F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k}^{g},\bm{v}_{k}^{g,\tau_{\bm{v}}},\xi_{k}^{g}) for τ^𝒖subscript^𝜏𝒖\hat{\tau}_{\bm{u}} iterations, and τ^𝒖subscript^𝜏𝒖\hat{\tau}_{\bm{u}} can be a small value according to [25, 26]. Then, the importance of each weight in the global part is calculated by (20), and the weights of the global part are sorted in descending order. With a pruning ratio ρkgsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝑔\rho_{k}^{g}, we deploy a pruning mask 𝒎kgsuperscriptsubscript𝒎𝑘𝑔\bm{m}_{k}^{g} to prune the global part 𝒖kgsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔\bm{u}_{k}^{g}, which is calculated as

𝒖kg,0=𝒖g⊙𝒎kg.superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔0direct-productsuperscript𝒖𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑘𝑔\bm{u}_{k}^{g,0}=\bm{u}^{g}\odot\bm{m}_{k}^{g}. (21)

In (21), the weights whose importance ranked last ρkg​Nk,𝒖kgsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑘subscript𝒖𝑘𝑔\rho_{k}^{g}N_{k,\bm{u}_{k}}^{g} are pruned, and Nk,𝒖kgsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑘subscript𝒖𝑘𝑔N_{k,\bm{u}_{k}}^{g} is the size of the global part. (22)

Given a pruning ratio ρkgsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝑔\rho_{k}^{g}, some unimportant weights are pruned and not transmitted to the edge server. 𝒖g+1,j=1|𝒦gj|​∑k∈𝒦gj𝒖kg,j.superscript𝒖𝑔1𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝒦𝑔𝑗subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒦𝑔𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔𝑗\bm{u}^{g+1,j}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{K}_{g}^{j}|}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}^{j}}\bm{u}_{k}^{g,j}. (26)

Similarly, the synchronous uplink transmission of the global part and local model updating in edge devices is considered; thus, the computation and uplink transmission latency in each global communication in (14) is updated as

T^g=maxk∈𝒦⁡{T^kg}.subscript^𝑇𝑔subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript^𝑇𝑘𝑔\hat{T}_{g}=\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{\hat{T}_{k}^{g}\}. (29)

To better illustrate the selected personalized and global parts in the proposed FL framework, we take a convolutional neural network (CNN) as an example, which is also used in experiment results. As shown in Fig. 2, CNN mainly includes an input layer, several convolution layers, several pooling layers, and a fully connected layer. In our work, the convolution layers and pooling layers are responsible for feature extraction, which belongs to the personalized parts. While the fully connected layers are used for pattern recognition, which belongs to the global parts. Model pruning in the convolution layers (personalized part) decreases the robust capability of CNN; thus, we mainly consider model pruning in the fully connected layers (global part).

III-B Proposed FL Convergence Analysis

According to [27] and [28], the average l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm of gradients is usually used to evaluate the convergence of the proposed FL framework. The following assumptions are used to facilitate convergence analysis of FL with partial model pruning and personalization.

Assumption 1. All loss functions Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘F_{k}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}) are continuously differentiable with respect to 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} and 𝒗ksubscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k}, namely, ∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)subscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘\nabla_{\bm{u}}F_{k}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}) is L𝒖subscript𝐿𝒖L_{\bm{u}}-Lipschitz continuous with 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}, and ∇𝒗Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)subscript∇𝒗subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘\nabla_{\bm{v}}F_{k}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}) is L𝒗subscript𝐿𝒗L_{\bm{v}}-Lipschitz continuous with 𝒗ksubscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k}, which are denoted as

‖∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)−∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖^,𝒗k)‖≤L𝒖​‖𝒖−𝒖^‖,normsubscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘subscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘^𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘subscript𝐿𝒖norm𝒖^𝒖\|\nabla_{\bm{u}}F_{k}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k})-\nabla_{\bm{u}}F_{k}(\hat{\bm{u}},\bm{v}_{k})\|\leq L_{\bm{u}}\|\bm{u}-\hat{\bm{u}}\|, (30)

and

‖∇𝒗Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)−∇𝒗Fk​(𝒖,𝒗^k)‖≤L𝒗​‖𝒗k−𝒗^k‖,normsubscript∇𝒗subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘subscript∇𝒗subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript^𝒗𝑘subscript𝐿𝒗normsubscript𝒗𝑘subscript^𝒗𝑘\|\nabla_{\bm{v}}F_{k}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k})-\nabla_{\bm{v}}F_{k}(\bm{u},\hat{\bm{v}}_{k})\|\leq L_{\bm{v}}\|\bm{v}_{k}-\hat{\bm{v}}_{k}\|, (31)

where L𝒖subscript𝐿𝒖L_{\bm{u}} and L𝒗subscript𝐿𝒗L_{\bm{v}} are positive constants.

Assumption 2. Global part pruning introduces noise and causes model error. Unlike the convergence analysis of FL with model personalization in [11] and [29], based on [15] and [30], the upper bound of model error caused by ρkgsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝑔\rho_{k}^{g} is expressed as

𝔼​‖𝒖kg−𝒖kg⊙𝒎kg‖2≤ρkg​D2,𝔼superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔direct-productsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑘𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝑔superscript𝐷2\mathbb{E}\|\bm{u}_{k}^{g}-\bm{u}_{k}^{g}\odot\bm{m}_{k}^{g}\|^{2}\leq\rho_{k}^{g}D^{2}, (32)

where D𝐷D is a positive constant.

Assumption 3. According to [31] and [32], the upper bound of the second moments of stochastic gradients of global and personalized parts are denoted as

𝔼​‖∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖kg,t,𝒗kg,t,ξkg,t)‖2≤ϕ𝒖2,𝔼superscriptnormsubscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑔𝑡2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝒖2\mathbb{E}\|\nabla_{\bm{u}}F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k}^{g,t},\bm{v}_{k}^{g,t},\xi_{k}^{g,t})\|^{2}\leq\phi_{\bm{u}}^{2}, (33)

and

𝔼​‖∇𝒗Fk​(𝒖kg,t,𝒗kg,t,ξkg,t)‖2≤ϕ𝒗2,𝔼superscriptnormsubscript∇𝒗subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑔𝑡2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝒗2\mathbb{E}\|\nabla_{\bm{v}}F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k}^{g,t},\bm{v}_{k}^{g,t},\xi_{k}^{g,t})\|^{2}\leq\phi_{\bm{v}}^{2}, (34)

respectively. In (33) and (34), ϕ𝒖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝒖\phi_{\bm{u}} and ϕ𝒗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝒗\phi_{\bm{v}} are positive constants, and ξkg,tsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑔𝑡\xi_{k}^{g,t} is the set consisting of mini-batch data samples for any k,g,t𝑘𝑔𝑡k,g,t.

𝔼​[∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖kg,t,ξkg,t)]=∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖kg,t),𝔼delimited-[]subscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑔𝑡subscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑔𝑡\mathbb{E}[\nabla_{\bm{u}}F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k}^{g,t},\xi_{k}^{g,t})]=\nabla_{\bm{u}}F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k}^{g,t}), (35)

and

and

𝑅𝑒𝑚𝑎𝑟𝑘​1::𝑅𝑒𝑚𝑎𝑟𝑘1absent\mathit{Remark~{}1:} Based on Theorem 1, we can obtain that given the number of iterations of both the global and personalized parts, the number of global communication rounds, and the learning rate, the upper bound of the convergence rate of the proposed FL is mainly determined by the pruning ratio. Therefore, we mainly consider optimizing the pruning ratio under the latency and bandwidth constraints.

III-C Optimization Problem Transformation

Motivated by Theorem 1, we need to maximize the convergence rate, and the optimization problem is reformulated as

minbkg,ρkgsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑔superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝑔\displaystyle\min_{{b}_{k}^{g},\rho_{k}^{g}}~{}~{} A2​∑g=1G∑k=1Kρkg,subscript𝐴2superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝑔\displaystyle A_{2}\sum_{g=1}^{G}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\rho_{k}^{g}, (43)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t.~{}~{} T^g≤Tth,subscript^𝑇𝑔subscript𝑇th\displaystyle\hat{T}_{g}\leq T_{\text{th}}, (44)
(17),(18)1718\displaystyle(17),(18)
ρkg∈[0,1].superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘𝑔01\displaystyle\rho_{k}^{g}\in[0,1]. (45)

The constraint in (45) represents the threshold of the pruning ratio. To minimize the global loss function, a proper pruning ratio of the global part and a proper bandwidth fraction of each edge device should be carefully selected based on the constraints in (17), (18), (44) and (45).

IV Pruning Ratio and Bandwidth Fraction Optimization

To optimize the pruning ratio and bandwidth fraction, the optimization problem in (43) is divided into two sub-problems.

IV-A Pruning Ratio Optimization

According to the constraint in (44), the computation and uplink transmission latency of the k𝑘kth edge device should not larger than the latency constraint, which is written as

Proof.

The optimization problem in (50) is equal to

According to KKT conditions, the optimal bandwidth allocation for each device is obtained as Theorem 3. ∎

In addition, the device with high computation capacity is allocated with more bandwidth, improving the convergence rate and decreasing computation latency. Detailed procedures of the proposed FL framework are shown in Algorithm 1.

V Experiment Results

This section examines our proposed FL framework. The experiment considers one edge server providing ten devices with wireless and global part aggregation services. The bandwidth allocated to the edge server is 20​MHz20MHz20~{}\text{MHz}, the transmission power of the device is 28​dBm28dBm28~{}\text{dBm}, the CPU frequency of the device is 3​GHz3GHz3~{}\text{GHz}, the quantization bit is 323232, the latency threshold is 25​ms25ms25~{}\text{ms}, and the AWGN noise power is −110​dBm110dBm-110~{}\text{dBm}. For the learning model, we consider CNN for image classification over MNIST and Fashion MNIST datasets. We set the convolutional layers and fully connected layers to be personalized and global parts, respectively. Both the learning rate of the personalized and global parts is 0.0010.0010.001. The mini-batch size is 128128128. Wireless channels transmit the global parts between the edge server and devices. The input size of CNN is 1 ×\times 28 ×\times 28, and the sizes of the first and second convolutional layers are 32 ×\times 28 ×\times 28 and 64 ×\times 14 ×\times 14, respectively. The sizes of the first and second max-pooling layers are 32×14×14 and 64 ×\times 7 ×\times 7, respectively. The sizes of the first and second fully connected layers are 3136 and 128, respectively. The size of the output layer is 10. Each device exclusively has data from several labels.

V-A FL with Partial Model Pruning and Personalization

The relationship between the loss value of the proposed FL and pruning ratios on non-IID MNIST and Fashion MNIST datasets is shown in Fig. 3 (a) and Fig. 3 (b), respectively. The performance of the testing accuracy with increasing pruning ratio of the proposed FL is shown in Fig. 3 (c). We find that the convergence rate decreases, and the value loss increases with the increasing pruning ratio. This is because more model weights are pruned with a higher pruning ratio, which leads to a lower learning ability. The comparison of the testing accuracy of the proposed FL by alternatively (FedAlt) and simultaneously (FedSim) local updating is plotted in Fig. 4. We observe that the testing accuracy of FedAlt is a bit higher than that of FedSim.

V-B Proposed FL over Wireless Networks

This section presents the performance of the joint design of pruning ratio and bandwidth fraction allocation for the proposed FL and how the latency threshold affects the proposed FL.

V-B1 Pruning Ratio and Bandwidth Fraction Optimization

Three baselines are considered to compare with the proposed FL. These three baselines are presented as follows.

  • •

    Equal Resource Pruning: The pruning ratio is optimized based on the equally allocated bandwidth.

  • •

    FL only with Model Personalization in [11]: In [11], only FL with model personalization is considered.

  • •

    FL only with Model Pruning in [15]: In [15], only FL with optimal model pruning was considered.

Table I shows the model updating and transmission latency of each global communication round of these four schemes mentioned above. It is shown that the computation and communication latency of the proposed FL is much smaller than that of the FL only with model pruning in [15] or the FL only with model personalization in [11]. This is because only the pruned global part needs to be transmitted between the edge server and devices. Also, it is observed that the latency of the proposed FL is smaller than that of the equal resource pruning scheme. This is because the proposed FL is able to select the optimal pruning ratio of the global part based on the allocated bandwidth, which further reduces the latency.

The performance comparison of joint optimization of pruning and bandwidth fraction optimization of the proposed FL with the other three baselines on the non-IID Fashion MNIST dataset is presented in Fig. 5 (a) and Fig. 5 (b), respectively. It is observed that the loss value and testing accuracy of the proposed FL framework are better than the equal resource pruning scheme and FL only with model pruning in [15]. This is because the joint design of pruning ratio and bandwidth allocation by KKT conditions is able to prune the unimportant weights based on dynamic wireless environments, and partial model personalization enables learning the data heterogeneity of different devices. Also, from Fig. 5 (a) and Fig. 5 (b), the learning performance of the proposed FL is close to FL only with partial model personalization. However, as shown in Fig. 5 (c), the communication cost is about 50%percent5050\% less than FL only with model personalization. The communication cost quantifies the number of model weights of the global part required to be delivered for model aggregation. This is because only the pruned global part needs to be transmitted to the edge server for model aggregation without sacrificing the learning performance.

V-B2 Effect of Latency Threshold

Four latency thresholds (15​ms15ms15\text{ms}, 20​ms20ms20\text{ms}, 25​ms25ms25\text{ms}, and 30​ms30ms30\text{ms}) are considered to show the effects on the proposed FL on the non-IID Fashion MNIST dataset in Fig. 6 (a) and Fig. 6 (b), respectively. Fig. 6 (c) shows the optimized pruning ratio calculated by KKT conditions satisfying the given latency constraints. It is obtained that with increasing latency thresholds, the loss value decreases, and the testing accuracy increases. Also, the number of global communication rounds achieving convergence becomes smaller with increasing latency thresholds. This is because a small pruning ratio is selected with a large latency threshold, and more important model weights of the global part are kept to improve the learning ability.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, a computation and communication-efficient FL framework with partial model pruning and personalization over wireless networks was proposed to adapt to data heterogeneity and dynamical wireless environments. Particularly, an upper bound on the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm of gradients for the proposed FL frameworks was derived. Subsequently, based on the convergence analysis of the proposed FL, the closed-form solutions of pruning ratio and bandwidth allocation were derived to maximize the convergence rate under latency and bandwidth thresholds by KKT conditions. Simulation results have demonstrated that our proposed FL framework achieved similar learning accuracy compared to FL only with partial model personalization and reduced about 50%percent5050\% computation and communication overheads.
